statement.p: Reduce the matrix A= \left[\begin{array}{cccc} -4 \amp -8 \amp -4 \amp -64\cr 0 \amp 4 \amp 6 \amp 40\cr 0 \amp -8 \amp -16 \amp -96 \end{array}\right] to reduced row-echelon form.

hint.p: First, do \frac{1}{-4} R_1 \to R_1, resulting in \left[\begin{array}{cccc} 1 \amp 2 \amp 1 \amp 16\cr 0 \amp 4 \amp 6 \amp 40\cr 0 \amp -8 \amp -16 \amp -96 \end{array}\right]

Then, do \frac{1}{4} R_2 \to R_2, resulting in \left[\begin{array}{cccc} 1 \amp 2 \amp 1 \amp 16\cr 0 \amp 1 \amp 1.5 \amp 10\cr 0 \amp -8 \amp -16 \amp -96 \end{array}\right] Next, do 8 R_2+R_3 \to R_3, resulting in \left[\begin{array}{cccc} 1 \amp 2 \amp 1 \amp 16\cr 0 \amp 1 \amp 1.5 \amp 10\cr 0 \amp 0 \amp -4 \amp -16 \end{array}\right]
Now we can multiply R_3 by a constant to create the leading 1, and then do the backwards steps.

statement.p: Reduce the matrix A= \left[\begin{array}{cccc} 1 \amp 3 \amp 4 \amp -2\cr 1 \amp -1 \amp 0 \amp -2\cr -3 \amp 3 \amp -2 \amp 4 \end{array}\right] to reduced row-echelon form.
